Great trailer, but to all the PC crowd yelling downgraded I never saw 
anything in the trailer that said this was actual gameplay. Looks more like 
pre-rendered target footage for what they were going for and honestly from 
the actual gameplay we've seen it does look amazing. Doesn't look as good 
as this, but then this was never actual gameplay.﻿

+Patrick Lauderdale It was actual gameplay... just freshened up and used 
for commercial 'DEMO" purposes only. This is what they show to get people 
excited, not what will run on the final system. All the volumetric smoke, 
and the special eye candy here was JUST for this trailer.

comments.text:
Many comments here speculating how the Witcher 3 will surpass over games 
such as Skyrim and Dragon Age.

Honestly, I don't see the need for such rivalry. Whilst The Elder Scrolls, 
Witcher and Dragon Age may all be fantasy games, they are all great in 
their own ways and each has their own unique feel to them - indeed that is 
what makes each series so excellent.﻿

You broke my heart with the later release date (the previous one was nearly 
my birthday present). I'm still pissing my pants with excitement, though. I 
lived and re-lived those books over and over again as a teenager. I can't 
wait to have Yennefer and Cirilla back. I hope that by taking your time you 
will only make their stories this much more epic. This game makes me proud 
to be Polish and I mean it. You push boundaries anywhere and everywhere. 
Even though I no longer live in Poland every Witcher makes me feel like I'm 
coming back home. ﻿

comments.text:
Oh well. 
I and many other people thought it did live up to the hype, and continued 
to play it even after a year. Nevermind - agree to disagree.
comments.author: Aethelred the forty-second

comments.text:
+Robert Burns
 I was talking about being overhyped. Skyrim had a lot of decent things 
going for it, but it's not what people often try to make it be. Critical 
acclaim isn't much when your mainstream medias are often targets of jokes 
when they rate a mediocre AAA title highly, and I never treat an unpopular 
opinion as something lesser. Just because something is popular doesn't mean 
it's amazing, just look at Justing Bieber. Skyrim can be simply summarized 
as Oblivion on steroids, by objective comparisons, and what I'm saying in 
the end is that it's not enough.
comments.author: Lefiath

comments.text:
+Lefiath People inevitably have different opinions. So whilst you may not 
have enjoyed it, it received critical acclaim, and many people were 
captivated by its world, and spent hours, days, months and years playing 
Skyrim. As I said in a different post: the Witcher, the Elder Scrolls and 
Dragon Age fantasy series are all excellent in their own wonderful ways.
comments.author: Aethelred the forty-second

comments.text:
+Ruben Fernandes Where is the immersion? Last time I went looking for it I 
got lost in deepest pits of blend characters, badly written dialogues, 
fetch quests, boring combat and in general doing same things over and over 
in a world that feels so fake I couldn't understand why nothing has changed 
since Oblivion. My biggest problem with Elder Scroll games is exactly how 
not immersive they are. Immersion doesn't mean better graphics or sounds, 
that's just a smaller part of it. Immersion can happen with much older 
games, simply because the world you are in feels genuine and alive. 

In Skyrim, you have to do everything, majority of your actions have little 
to no consequences, and majority of characters are completely forgettable 
and they don't register most of the things you're doing. Yes, there is a 
lot of concent and some of it is good, but the game itself is one of the 
most overhyped ones I've ever seen. Only thanks to the mods I've been able 
to make this game feel more alive and immersive, especially with better 
NPCs that actually reacted to things I was doing, which blew my mind, 
because the vanilla NPCs will only shout generic nonsense at me all the 
time and if something breaks my immersion, it's a robot that's doing 
something over and over despite me interacting with world he's part of.
comments.author: Lefiath

comments.text:
+urbium Skyrim didn't have too much to offer in terms of choice-consequence 
and a fairly linear story, and it is over-rated. However, its true strength 
was its world. Very large, very beautiful and very immersive - many players 
felt absolutely captivated by it - and certainly deserves to be honoured on 
some sort of pedestal (although the witcher probably will topple it.)
comments.author: Aethelred the forty-second

comments.text:
+echomjp Skyrim definitely redefined the RPG genre BUT in terms of how big 
it was: the world exploration, detailed world where every location has its 
own story. 

But the real RPG values in it are not existing. 

Choices and consequences, which are by far the most important things in an 
RPG games, don't exist! There are only a couple of choices where there's 
some kind of consequences, like whether you destroy Dark Brotherhood or 
join them, or the civil war questline. Some very important decisions have 
no consequence whatsoever, you kill Paarthurnax but nothing happens 
afterwards besides Greybeards telling you that you betrayed them. 

Memorable characters? Maybe, but just a handful of them, Cicero, 
Paarthurnax and Serana, that's really it. Can't remember anyone else. Most 
of them were really unmemorable and had no personality. While, for example 
in Witcher 2, one of the characters who was memorable to me is a fist 
fighting announcer. And that's only a trivial character, you can imagine 
how memorable the main characters were to me...


Immersive story and side quests? Story was cliché, mediocre and linear, a 
hero who will save the world from dragons blah, blah, blah... Side quests: 
the miscellaneous quests were just a filler, retrieve that sword from this 
crypt, deliver this ring to that guy, find the specific book, kill that 
guy... And there's about 5 of each of those quests in a game, it's lazy. 
Faction quests were mostly ok. The "bigger" side quests, which have the 
name, were imo the best quests of the game, I really liked some of them, 
like the Forbidden Legend, Blood on Ice and Forsworn Conspiracy.

Overall, Skyrim was a good game and an ok RPG, an RPG that doesn't have 
most of its crucial components that I discussed about. It may be on some 
kind of throne, but the RPG throne, it is not.
comments.author: Lazar  Šutilović

comments.text:
+Ruben Fernandes Are you for real man?. Zenimax-Bethesda are the same 
company so it's doesn't matter if it's doing crap or not. A new TES game

comments.text:
+Rockman Rossi I can't wait for the next Elder Scrolls but I think The 
Witcher 3 is going to be AWESOOOMMMMMEEEEE!!! CAN'T WAIT!!!!
comments.author: Alan Honore

comments.text:
+Can Toros Yes, it did redefined rpg games for a lot of people, for me, the 
best rpg games used to be dungeon and dragons and similar games (pool of 
radiance, temple of elemental evil, neverwinter nights), but since i 
started playing oblivion and skyrim, they kinda lost their roleplaying 
effect:
On D&D, you just give orders to the characters, attack successes or fails 
where based on points and a dice roll, you had a limited control in the 
world... On Elder scrolls, YOU'RE THE CHARACTER, there's immersion, skills 
are based on usage and training instead of points, it feels like a 
secondary virtual life in a world that gives you a purpose, you do quests 
because you feel like doing them and not because the game forces you to do 
them if you want to advance, you sometimes even kill characters because 
they did or said something, it became personal because it felt like it was 
towards you and not your virtual avatar.
comments.author: Ruben Fernandes (Rauven)

comments.text:
+Can Toros
Yeah. It defined the RPG because the majority of people and media that 
plays RPGs decided that it defined it. Definitions after all are arbitrary.

Also, +urbium , I'm not sure what you meant by "proper RPG". If you define 
an RPG as what it typically always has been defined as - a role-playing 
game where you play a character and progress that character through a 
world, it is definitely proper. It has leveling and a bunch of class 
progression, it has a central plot that you affect through your actions, 
and it allows you to play many roles.

So, a role playing game.

Also, popularity most certainly does not denote quality - but then Skyrim 
is not low quality by any RPG standard I've ever seen. Even if it was, to 
argue something as not proper or defining due to it being low quality would 
be similar to arguing that World of Warcraft does not define MMOs. It isn't 
important whether or not the core game is mediocre by genre standards 
(which themselves are poor for mmos), only whether or not people perceive 
it as good (IE, popularity).

Now, if you want to argue Skyrim was over-rated, I can only agree, but to 
argue it wasn't a proper RPG or that it didn't define RPGs at the time it 
was released (or even now still) is to be at odds with reality itself.

If any of you have particular reasons as to why I am wrong, I'm all ears 
(or eyes in this case), but honestly speaking two comments that respond to 
me but do not address any point I make won't get anyone far.
comments.author: echomjp

comments.text:
Wooow, woow, wait a second, in the trailer at 0:31 - 0:35 we see 5 witcher, 
including Geralt, who is shown last, i persume that these 4 witchers are 
Vesimir, Lambert, Eskel and...... Letho, he is persumably the man we see at 
0:31, a witcher that has big arms, bassicly a physique of a body builder on 
steroids that Letho has. Now il tell you why i think its him and not 
somebody else.
In the first instalment of The Witcher, we have seen 5 witchers, and all of 
these 5 were from kaer morhen witcher school, untill one of them was 
killed, a "freshman" called Leo, he is/was a witcher but, lets say, not 
totaly a witcher - "He's not a full witcher though he has completed his 
training, he was not subjected to mutation.".
And since it says in the trailer  "Once we were many, now we are few", it 
would be logical to put Letho in this trailer to show off how many are 
there now. I might be wrong, but i think im like 80-90% positive that it is 
Letho, if not than... pff mate, who could it be?
Any ideas people?﻿
comments.author: Domagoj Stivic

comments.text:
This is Letho for sure. Probably will be in the gameplay if you've played 
W2 and choosed not to kill him. About other witchers roiking2740 may be 
right but I wouldn't go above the number of 15 if we are considering game 
time. So there are 3 main witcher schools according to Sapkowski's work. 
Viper school is a game thing but we can assume there were 6 witchers living 
until the first attempt of killing Foltest (W1 ending misterious witcher is 
killed by Geralt) then Auckes and Serrit died and at the end of the game 
Letho says that he knows of 2 remainning witchers from viper school. In 
wolf school after Geralt's death (end of books and beginning of games) as 
we add content from game we know that there are 5 witchers from this school 
(Coen dies in books) - Geralt, Lambert, Eskel, Berengar and Vesemir. Leo 
has not accomplished the trail of grass and is dead so we exclude him. 
Berengar is dead after the fight with Azar Javed (you may save him but I 
don't think devs meant for him to survive). We don't have informations 
about the griffin school as it is probably ruined but I guess it's safe to 
say that there are maybe 3-4 witchers on path. Some may survived from 
whatever happend to the school. We got to remember that witchers most of 
the time wondered across many kingdoms looking for work and during the 
winter they returned to their strongholds. About the cat school things may 
complicate a little bit because we can add new source - comics. But I would 
rather not complicate things. We can conclude from them that wolf and cat 
school didn't like each other. Last book from Sapkowski confirms that as 
Geralt confronts Brehen - witcher from cat school. We can also say that 
there may be about 5 witchers remaining from that school but they are not 
so noble as they brothers from other schools (as if all witchers were noble 
:P). Cat's witchers are considering murderers and spies. So my thought is 
that in the game we will probably meet only 4 witchers - Letho, Eskel, 
Vesemir and Lambert but hell this game is so huge and devs in CDProjekt Red 
are so full of new ideas and imagination that it might be possible that we 
will meet new ones. As it goes for Witcher universum I think that the 
number of witchers could be between 10-20 but as we see and as we progress 
in games we can say that fewer and fewer witchers in this world and they 
are truly a dying breed.
comments.author: Dziordan1

comments.text:
in the book it says that witchers stick to the wilds sense most citiies 
treat them like shit. i only assume there are about 2 dozen left. also the 
emperor of nighiffguard promise letho to revive the viper school and he 
also mentioned witchers coming out of hidding there so i assume he knows 
more witchers are alive.

in neither the games nor the books how many witchers are left. All we know 
about in certainty are the wolf and viper schools. Maybe I missed something?

(Also, Domagoj, that probably is Letho, yeah)
